elements.name: appdev1
elements.title: How are software projects organised and delivered?

choices.text: Follow a sequential process of analysis, design, implementation, testing and release.
Some iterative practices within specific teams, supporting delivery of larger programmes
A iterative delivery approach with a product backlog, definition of done, and retrospectives, with a hand-off to operations that is largely independent of software development.
Business, application development and delivery have aligned Agile practices.  Ownership of production is within cross functional application team.
Agile process with quantifiable metrics based on systems in production. Fast feedback loops, designed to verify and quantify strategic goals, and desired business outcomes.

elements.name: question7
elements.title: What best describes the level of governance and control within your organization?

choices.text: No commonly implemented change policy, new changes can be introduced at any point through software delivery lifecycle
Change policy is sometimes bypassed for expediency, or change seen as critical to success.

Standard processes and architectures have developed over time, with addendums to support some new technologies and capabilities, but lack of ownership has led to complications and a low understanding of the rationale in some cases
There are common approaches supporting the delivery and architecture across the software delivery lifecycle, incorporating good levels of transparency and adapability.

There are processes in place that allow measurement of the business value of multiple software versions running simultaneously in production, coupled with team-level authority to make end-of-life decisions on specific versions.

elements.title: When building new I.T. processes, is automation a before or after thought?

choices.text: Before
During
After

elements.name: q_automation_2
elements.title: Are operational standards shared across the organization or are decisions made individually?

choices.text: Technology decisions are always solely within the department
Technology decisions are sometimes made solely within the department

elements.name: q_automation_3
elements.title: What best describes your current culture and process related to automating tasks?

choices.text: Siloed process
DevOps team created to change processes
Automation teams have been created across the organization
Multiple teams automating their components and contributing to a central repository

elements.name: q_automation_4
elements.title: On a scale of 1 (same without automation) to 5 (fully updated to support the modern environment), rate your security practices

choices.text: no automation used; security requirements applied manually
scheduling the change window and taking things offline are implemented manually; scripts are deployed for patches
utilizing some automation to supply some things (OS hardening/patching)
validation has been applied via automation; security processes are defined in a workflow
all your security items are applied through automation; complete end-to-end workflow of security functions including validation

elements.name: q_automation_5
elements.title: On a scale of 1 (have not) to 5 (fully implemented) rate the amount of automation your organization has deployed.

choices.text: no automation used
teams of people writing ad-hoc scripts for automation
standardized on an automation platform; beginning to automate processes
able to auotmate all of your day 2 tasks
all applications deployed; monitoring alerts and other IT day-to-day are automated

elements.name: q_automation_6
elements.title: Do multiple teams within your organization create and share automation content in a consistent, standardized manner?

elements.name: q_automation_7
elements.title: How would you describe the level of IT automation for application development and deploymeent in your environment OVERALL?

choices.text: Level 1 Many manual steps throughout the SDLC including testing, patching, configuration, release and deployment.
Level 2 Overall processes manually coordinated, but with the emergence of scripting for simplifying repeated steps.
Level 3 Automation coordinating the processes, with some automated testing, and the emergence of declarative configuration implementation.
Level 4 Significant reuse of delivery automation and automated testing now including operational concerns, but release frequency somewhat impeded by complexity of application code and configuration.

Level 5 Software deployed to production before a managed release, with production issues being resolved through a test driven approach. Self service infrastructure with zero or little manual intervention required.

elements.name: q_automation_8
elements.title: When you think about rolling out NEW applications, rate on a scale of 1 to 5 how automated your application deployment is

choices.text: Manual deployment, no process or automation
Minimal deployment with ad-hoc scripting, not repeatable
Baseline continuous integration (CI) processing (unit tests, manual testing)
Advanced CI, greater than 90% automated testing, pipelines, approval gateways
Full continuous integration / continuous delivery (CI/CD) from development into production (greater than 90%)

elements.name: q_automation_9
elements.title: When you think about rolling out LEGACY application updates, rate on a scale of 1 to 5 how automated your application deployment is

choices.text: Manual deployment, no process or automation
Minimal deployment with ad-hoc scripting, not repeatable
Baseline continuous integration (CI) processing (unit tests, manual testing)
Advanced CI, greater than 90% automated testing, pipelines, approval gateways
Full continuous integration / continuous delivery (CI/CD) from development into production (greater than 90%)
